BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 24, 1922
THE DRAMATIC CLUB PRODUCTION
On Monday and Tuesday nights The Dramatic Club presents
for the approval of the Student Body and the City of Baltimore its
production of the year, "If I Were King."
The club has suffered unusual difficulties this year in the form
of both natural and unnatural competition. There are a number of
shows being presented this month, most of them directed by professional organizers and producers, creating this work as a means of
existence. These, however, may be considered natural forms of
competition.
The other form, which put in its appearance recently, when a
newly-formed organization presented several one-act plays at the
Barn, should never have occurred.
Both the Hopkins Dramatic Club and the Homewood Playshop
should have opportunity for displaying their talents. It should be
remembered, however, that the Dramatic Club is much the older organization and is the only recognized Hopkins dramatic activity.
The Playshop is composed of graduate students, faculty members,
and others distantly associated with the University. These people
are also entitled to their opportunities before the footlights, but we
hope that in the future they may present their offering at a time more
convenient to the undergraduate body.
At present, our entire attention should be directed towards our
production, the only purely amateur, college presentation of the
year.

THE PUBLICITY BOARD AND ITS PURPOSE
There seems to be some confusion in the minds of certain members of both the student body and the faculty as to the exact purpose
of the Publicity Board.
The following letter was received by the Editor-in-chief of the
Board:
"Why should the Publicity Board desire to attract a large number of students to Hopkins when the University is limited to an
enrollment of less than 700 undergraduates?
"Further, why should the University be advertised solely through
its athletic achievements? This last question was put to me by a
member of the faculty. . . ."
It is perfectly obvious that the writer of this letter has not followed the occasional explanations that have appeared in the NewsLetter.
The Athletic Board and the Student Council, in sponsoring the
Publicity Board work, realized that a flood of applications for entrance to the University would enable the authorities to make a
careful selection, using the past records of the applicants as evidence
of their ability. In addition to this the enrollment of a number of outof-town students will help to make the dormitories the center of
student life.
As to the second question, concerning the release of athletic
information as the sole means of advertising the University, there
seems to be further evidence of confusion.
As revealed by the records of the Board, the release of information has been divided equally between athletic and non-athletic activities.
The aim of the organization is, not to improve the University by
quantity, but by quality.
With the aid of the Publicity Board, and the State Legislature,
in repealing the law compelling the state universities to accept graduates of state high schools, Hopkins will eventually become an exclusive institution.

The Institute of International
Education has given its official
sponsorship to a group of four educational tours to European countries, organized under the auspices
of the Institute and of other international groups for the purpose of
enabling American college students
and instructors to travel more
cheaply and more profitably than
would be possible under any other
conditions.
The International
Students'
Tours differ in several essential respects from any other plan for organized travel; first, in their noncommercial character; second, in
their educational and international
significance; third, in the fact that
membership is restricted to persons
associated with American colleges
and schools, either as teachers or as
students; and, fourth, in the fact
that the Students' Tours have been
granted unusual courtesies by the
Governments and Universities of
the countries to be visited.
During the coming summer there
will be four Students' Tours, as follows:
Students' Tour to Great Britain.
Students' Tour to France.
Students' Tour to Italy.
Students' Tour to the Scandinavian Countries.
The members of all four of the
Students' Tours will sail from New
York on July 1, 1922, on the Cunarder ."Saxonia." For the return
trip, all of the groups will embark
at Cherbourg on August 22, due to
arrive in New York on September 1.
The details of administration are
being handled by Mr. Irwin Smith,
Director of the International Students' Tours, New York City, from
whom full information may be secured. The fee for membership in
each of the Students' Tours is $675

NATURALISTS FIELD CLUB PREPARE HOMES FOR SONGSTERS

Equipped with a ladder, a hammer and nails, and blue prints of
the campus, half a dozen members
of the Naturalists' Field Club, under the leadership of Dr. Cowles,
ventured forth last Saturday into
the chill March winds to inspect the
bird-cover at Homewood, and to
have them in readiness for the songsters when they begin their housekeeping operations next month.
The boxes were opened and filled
with sawdust. Only two houses
were found tO"have'been used, the
larger probably by a bluebird and
the other by a wren. In the wren
box was found evidence of a tragedy of the woods. A whole egg remained in the bottom of the nest,
while on the interior walls of the
box a colony of mud-dauber wasps
had plastered their spider-filled
cells. It was conjectured that the
insects had stung, or at least worried, the setting birds from their
eggs. Dr. Cowles believed that
most of the boxes were too high to
please the nest makers, and in consequence the highest were moved to
about fifteen feet from the ground.
The nest boxes had already been
numbered, but the numbers were
now marked upon the blue prints,
and all data concerning them re
corded. They will thus serve a twofold purpose, give shelter to the
birds and to the Naturalists know!.
edge of the birds' habits. There are
about thirty bird boxes on. the
campus, and of these seventeen were
put into condition last Saturday.
The others will be attended to in
the near futlire.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 24, 1922
THE DRAMATIC CLUB PRODUCTION
On Monday and Tuesday nights The Dramatic Club presents
for the approval of the Student Body and the City of Baltimore its
production of the year, "If I Were King."
The club has suffered unusual difficulties this year in the form
of both natural and unnatural competition. There are a number of
shows being presented this month, most of them directed by professional organizers and producers, creating this work as a means of
existence. These, however, may be considered natural forms of
competition.
The other form, which put in its appearance recently, when a
newly-formed organization presented several one-act plays at the
Barn, should never have occurred.
Both the Hopkins Dramatic Club and the Homewood Playshop
should have opportunity for displaying their talents. It should be
remembered, however, that the Dramatic Club is much the older organization and is the only recognized Hopkins dramatic activity.
The Playshop is composed of graduate students, faculty members,
and others distantly associated with the University. These people
are also entitled to their opportunities before the footlights, but we
hope that in the future they may present their offering at a time more
convenient to the undergraduate body.
At present, our entire attention should be directed towards our
production, the only purely amateur, college presentation of the
year.

THE PUBLICITY BOARD AND ITS PURPOSE
There seems to be some confusion in the minds of certain members of both the student body and the faculty as to the exact purpose
of the Publicity Board.
The following letter was received by the Editor-in-chief of the
Board:
"Why should the Publicity Board desire to attract a large number of students to Hopkins when the University is limited to an
enrollment of less than 700 undergraduates?
"Further, why should the University be advertised solely through
its athletic achievements? This last question was put to me by a
member of the faculty. . . ."
It is perfectly obvious that the writer of this letter has not followed the occasional explanations that have appeared in the NewsLetter.
The Athletic Board and the Student Council, in sponsoring the
Publicity Board work, realized that a flood of applications for entrance to the University would enable the authorities to make a
careful selection, using the past records of the applicants as evidence
of their ability. In addition to this the enrollment of a number of outof-town students will help to make the dormitories the center of
student life.
As to the second question, concerning the release of athletic
information as the sole means of advertising the University, there
seems to be further evidence of confusion.
As revealed by the records of the Board, the release of information has been divided equally between athletic and non-athletic activities.
The aim of the organization is, not to improve the University by
quantity, but by quality.
With the aid of the Publicity Board, and the State Legislature,
in repealing the law compelling the state universities to accept graduates of state high schools, Hopkins will eventually become an exclusive institution.

The Institute of International
Education has given its official
sponsorship to a group of four educational tours to European countries, organized under the auspices
of the Institute and of other international groups for the purpose of
enabling American college students
and instructors to travel more
cheaply and more profitably than
would be possible under any other
conditions.
The International
Students'
Tours differ in several essential respects from any other plan for organized travel; first, in their noncommercial character; second, in
their educational and international
significance; third, in the fact that
membership is restricted to persons
associated with American colleges
and schools, either as teachers or as
students; and, fourth, in the fact
that the Students' Tours have been
granted unusual courtesies by the
Governments and Universities of
the countries to be visited.
During the coming summer there
will be four Students' Tours, as follows:
Students' Tour to Great Britain.
Students' Tour to France.
Students' Tour to Italy.
Students' Tour to the Scandinavian Countries.
The members of all four of the
Students' Tours will sail from New
York on July 1, 1922, on the Cunarder ."Saxonia." For the return
trip, all of the groups will embark
at Cherbourg on August 22, due to
arrive in New York on September 1.
The details of administration are
being handled by Mr. Irwin Smith,
Director of the International Students' Tours, New York City, from
whom full information may be secured. The fee for membership in
each of the Students' Tours is $675

NATURALISTS FIELD CLUB PREPARE HOMES FOR SONGSTERS

Equipped with a ladder, a hammer and nails, and blue prints of
the campus, half a dozen members
of the Naturalists' Field Club, under the leadership of Dr. Cowles,
ventured forth last Saturday into
the chill March winds to inspect the
bird-cover at Homewood, and to
have them in readiness for the songsters when they begin their housekeeping operations next month.
The boxes were opened and filled
with sawdust. Only two houses
were found tO"have'been used, the
larger probably by a bluebird and
the other by a wren. In the wren
box was found evidence of a tragedy of the woods. A whole egg remained in the bottom of the nest,
while on the interior walls of the
box a colony of mud-dauber wasps
had plastered their spider-filled
cells. It was conjectured that the
insects had stung, or at least worried, the setting birds from their
eggs. Dr. Cowles believed that
most of the boxes were too high to
please the nest makers, and in consequence the highest were moved to
about fifteen feet from the ground.
The nest boxes had already been
numbered, but the numbers were
now marked upon the blue prints,
and all data concerning them re
corded. They will thus serve a twofold purpose, give shelter to the
birds and to the Naturalists know!.
edge of the birds' habits. There are
about thirty bird boxes on. the
campus, and of these seventeen were
put into condition last Saturday.
The others will be attended to in
the near futlire.
